transcript:
Therapist: As we wrap up our work together, I want to emphasize how much progress you've made, Alejandro. You've developed a strong set of skills for managing your depression, from challenging negative thoughts to practicing self-compassion and building a support network. I have full confidence in your ability to continue using these tools and maintaining your mental health.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. It's been a challenging journey, but I feel like I've learned a lot about myself and how to cope with my depression. I know there will be tough times ahead, but I feel more prepared to handle them now.

Therapist: That's wonderful to hear, Alejandro. Remember, progress isn't always linear, and there may be setbacks along the way. But with the skills you've developed and the resilience you've shown, I know you can weather those challenges and continue moving forward.

Patient: I appreciate your faith in me. It means a lot to have your support.

Therapist: Before we end our session, I want to assign some homework to help you continue practicing your CBT skills. First, I'd like you to continue using your thought records and coping cards regularly, especially when you notice negative thoughts or difficult emotions arising. Second, I encourage you to keep working with the music notation software and exploring new ways to express yourself musically. Finally, I'd like you to review your wellness action plan daily and make any updates or additions as needed.

Patient: That sounds good. I'll make sure to keep practicing my skills and updating my plan.

Therapist: Great. And remember, if you ever find yourself struggling or in need of additional support, don't hesitate to reach out. My door is always open.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. I'll keep that in mind.

Therapist: Before we wrap up, I want to do a final check-in on your current mood and any thoughts or feelings you have about ending our therapy sessions.

Patient: I'm feeling a mix of emotions right now. I'm proud of the progress I've made, but I'm also a bit nervous about continuing on my own. At the same time, I feel more equipped to handle challenges than I did when we started.

Therapist: It's completely normal to feel a mix of emotions at the end of therapy. It's a significant transition, and it's okay to feel both proud and nervous. Remember, you have the skills and the resilience to continue making progress, and you have a strong support network to lean on when needed.

Patient: That's a good reminder. I know I'm not alone in this journey.

Therapist: Exactly. And with that, I think we can wrap up our final session. Alejandro, it has been an honor and a privilege to work with you over these past 20 sessions. I am so proud of the progress you've made and the hard work you've put in. I have full confidence in your ability to continue using your CBT skills and maintaining your mental health.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. I couldn't have done it without your guidance and support. I'm grateful for everything you've taught me.

Therapist: You're very welcome, Alejandro. Remember, you have the tools and the strength to continue on this path. I wish you all the best in your journey ahead.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. I appreciate everything you've done for me.

Session Summary:
- Main topics discussed:
  - Reviewed the patient's experience with the music notation software and explored the emotions and thoughts that arose
  - Completed a thought record to challenge negative thoughts related to the patient's musical identity and worth
  - Reviewed and updated the patient's wellness action plan
  - Discussed the patient's progress, challenges, and feelings about ending therapy
- Techniques or exercises used:
  - Thought challenging technique (ongoing)
  - Behavioral activation (ongoing)
  - Self-compassion (ongoing)
  - Distress tolerance techniques (ongoing)
  - Cognitive distortions and reframing (ongoing)
  - Thought records (reviewed and practiced)
  - Coping cards (reviewed and assigned as ongoing homework)
  - Problem-solving techniques (introduced for breaking down tasks)
  - Wellness action plan (reviewed and assigned as ongoing homework)
  - Meta-thought records (introduced to address concerns about ending therapy)
  - Gradual termination (tapering off sessions to ease transition)
- Homework assigned:
  - Continue using thought records and coping cards regularly, focusing on challenging negative thoughts and reinforcing new, more balanced beliefs about worth
  - Keep working with the music notation software and exploring new ways to express yourself musically
  - Review the wellness action plan daily and make any updates or additions as needed
- Patient's progress:
  - Demonstrating increased insight into the connection between thoughts, emotions, and behaviors
  - Showing a willingness to challenge negative thoughts and consider alternative perspectives
  - Engaging in self-reflection and exploring aspects of identity outside of musical abilities
  - Taking steps to build a more balanced and comprehensive self-view
  - Showing openness to reframing vulnerability and considering the benefits of sharing struggles with others
  - Developing a plan for maintaining progress after therapy ends, including creating a wellness action plan
- Patient's challenges:
  - Grieving the loss of musical abilities and struggling with feelings of worthlessness
  - Difficulty engaging with others and building new connections in the support group
  - Struggling to internalize a more balanced and compassionate view of self-worth
  - Managing concerns and anxieties about ending therapy
- Depression symptoms:
  - Persistent sadness
  - Loss of interest
  - Feelings of worthlessness
  - Insomnia
  - Diminished appetite and weight loss
- Important personal details:
  - Hispanic male, 70 years old
  - Retired music professor
  - Diagnosed with Parkinson's disease
  - Lives alone
  - Limited social support network
- Core beliefs and intermediate beliefs:
  - Core belief: "I am worthless without my musical abilities."
  - Intermediate belief: "If I can't play music like I used to, then I'm not a real musician."
- Plan for next session:
  - This was the final scheduled therapy session. The patient is encouraged to continue practicing CBT skills independently and to reach out if additional support is needed in the future.
